title: How to Patch a Single Ply Membrane Roof

steps.headline: Identify the problem.
steps.description: Find the injury in the single-ply membrane.

steps.headline: Decide on the part to be cut away.
Replace insulation if needed with like material.
steps.description: Here insulation was used as a kind of underlayment.

steps.headline: Clean the membrane where the patch is to be applied.
steps.description: Start with a simple, all-purpose cleaner/degreaser, such as 409 or Simple Green.

steps.headline: Remove any soapy film.
steps.description: Rinse and thoroughly dry the area to be patched.

steps.headline: Line up patch correctly.
steps.description: Work across peeling away release film in stages while pressing in place as you go. One source of this material may be a building supply center or a recreational vehicle supply store.

steps.headline: Roll the butyl backed tape firmly into place.
steps.description: This requires utilizing a firm roller to assure contact.

steps.headline: Caulk around the edges of the patch with a bead of polyurethane sealant and cover the seam consistently.
steps.description: Notice on the left where the sealant is beginning to be spread only slightly to be sure it is still thick but well guided into place.

text: Identify the problem. Find the injury in the single-ply membrane. Decide on the part to be cut away. Remove damaged membrane and insulation. Replace insulation if needed with like material. Here insulation was used as a kind of underlayment. Clean the membrane where the patch is to be applied. Start with a simple, all-purpose cleaner/degreaser, such as 409 or Simple Green. Remove any soapy film. Rinse and thoroughly dry the area to be patched. Line up patch correctly. Work across peeling away release film in stages while pressing in place as you go. One source of this material may be a building supply center or a recreational vehicle supply store. Roll the butyl backed tape firmly into place. This requires utilizing a firm roller to assure contact. Caulk around the edges of the patch with a bead of polyurethane sealant and cover the seam consistently. Notice on the left where the sealant is beginning to be spread only slightly to be sure it is still thick but well guided into place.
